summary: A charismatic evil genius named Sir August de Wynter (Sean Connery) discovers a way to harness the weather and utilize it as a weapon against London and the world at large. The posh and droll combo of secret agents John Steed (Ralph Fiennes) and Emma Peel (Uma Thurman) are on the case. But then Peel is implicated in the sabotage of a government scientific experiment. Steed and Peel try to clear her name, while also trying to stop de Wynter for good.

reviews.content: At first I thought it might not be bad. But when the special effects and less-than-thrilling action began to appear and the immaturity of the script became apparent, I realized that my initial thought was a mistake.
It was like watching the director, producer and writers take a long, big shit all over my beloved British mod series. Possibly the worst movie of all times.

The Avengers isn't exactly a terrible movie. It has interesting visuals and some fun tidbits. It seems it can't commit to a tone, and there is no sense of urgency in the pacing, which makes the barely 90-minute film feel like a slog.
I wish for a director's cut.
A ghastly pastiche that has offended everyone by treading on sacred ground in a hackneyed attempt to replicate something great.
IT IS THE WORST MOVIE THAT HAS EVER BEEN MADE!
What's the point of having Eddie Izzard in your movie if you never let him speak?
One word : Disastrous.
it wasnt even reviewd by common sense media
A fair attempt to bring the old Avengers back from Dead TV shows.  But nothing can beat Emma Peel.
Too bad Thanos didn't snap these Avengers out of existence.

Well this was bad You have a talented Director and a superb cast but when you have bad writing,eff effects and bad editing this is one of the worst movies I ever seen and one of the worst movie ever made plus it's a disgrace to the groovy 60s spy tv show of the same name. This Thriller has clones bears and invisible man oh my indeed!
Pure cheese but entertainingly so.

Proof that the wrong actors with the wrong script in a film made by the wrong people is inevitably doomed to fail, and what a disappointment. As a super fan of the classic '60's British TV show, this film is an abomination and an insult to fans of the original program. Shameful.

Today's Viewing: 1998's "The Avengers". No, Not The "Avengers" YOU'RE Probably Thinking Of. This Action Spy Film, Based On The 1960s Espionage TV Series By Sydney Newman (Which I Have Not Seen, Honestly), Is EXTREMELY Underwhelming To Bear! The Story, The Characters, The Lines, The Sets, EVERYTHING Is Ungodly Boring & Nonsensical. Halfway Through The 1st Act Of The Film, I Automatically Don't Like This Movie. It Happens THAT Quick! Damn!

Like I Said, I Don't Feel Anything In This Flick; We Have To Sit Through Painfully Boring Chit-Chat, There's No Funny Jokes In Sight Whatsoever, &....Winnie The Pooh's "Care Bear" Cult?.......WTFF?!! Nothing Makes NO Sense! The Acting Is Dull, Not Even The Great Sean Connery Can Save This Movie! And As For Uma Thurman, Who's STILL A Cutie 😘, Her Acting Is, I'm Not Gonna Fib Here, Bad. Why, You May Ask? Well,...........SHE'S...NOT....BRITISH!!! 😤

There Is Nothing Else I Can Say About This Movie. Seriously, Nothing! 1998's "The Avengers" Is As Dull As A Rock In The Fuckin' Grass! It's A Lameass Piece Of Shit That Has Nothing To "Avenge" For It! Literally.

God, where to start? Inappropriate director, action scenes that aren't exciting, Fiennes and Thurman out of tune and Sean Connery gives a devilish speech wearing a kilt. Don't pay to see how shameful all that is.
I could be watching a better movie now...
After watching 1st 15-30 minutes, I realized, this is garbage

theres not a person in this cast who isnt a great actor and the series i watched when i was in high school and loved with diana rigg and patrick macnee was so good i never missed it but what did they do to this mess just awful
It is what it is.  A cheesy movie that isn't all that bad if watched for free...
Wanted to watch this becuase it had three great stars, acting was alright but the plot wasn't.

Unsure of just how seriously it's meant to be taken, this adaptation of the '60s TV show has a riveting opening act and another Oscar-worthy performance from Ralph Fiennes but after that, the movie is a poorly written and awfully edited mess with a bad performance from Uma Thurman and a cheesy attempt at a British accent and even sillier costumes - Batman & Robin's table scraps? - to go with it and blatant disregard for continuity thanks to studio interference resulting in a movie of this calibre being far too short. True, this movie is an absolute mess but if it's good for one thing, it's good for playing an April Fool's prank on your superhero-obsessed buddies.
So boring and so sense
I see why they opened it a day early to get some money before the reviews that it is a clunker came out.
This is one of the worst pieces of garbage ever put to film. Must watch. Especially to see uma thurman throw down against Eddie izzard. On a high wire
What a horrible movie with a dumb black widow rip off and a stupid top hat guy no one cares about
i cant lie, when it comes on its one of those movies i have to watch. its outlandish, bad plotted and acting is subpar. Ralph Fiennes though i think saves it and makes it entertaining.
oh god... OH GOD WHY? i hated this movie

As any hardcore fan of the TV series knows, no actress was ever going to be able to fill the tights of icons like Honor Blackman and Diana Rigg. The producers should have known such fans would provide not an instant audience but an army of instant deplorers many of whom notoriously refused to even see the movie. What idiot producer then provides not just one unacceptable Uma, but adds a second unacceptable Uma in the bargain (Uma's dual role as both Emma Peel and nemesis)?  Poor Uma never stood a chance, given she is a notoriously verveless actress especially compared to Diana Rigg. Uma turned out to be much more suited to originating roles that she was capable of playing (see Pulp Fiction, Kill Bill). As bad an idea as casting Thurman (or anyone in a film that shouldn't have been made), there was a great idea in casting Connery as the Bondian villain and this was the only potential drawing power the film really had (it was the only reason I went to see it!).  Connery appears to be having the time of his life portraying the essence of maniacal glee. The script is awful, even if the science is not gibberish it's delivered at such breakneck speed it comes off as such.  The actors spout dialogue at each other to zero reaction, like each one is occupying a separate room. Fiennes is credible in the action scenes, but otherwise is so bland as to blend into the wallpaper. If Patrick MacNee had feared being outdone in the role, they turned out to be groundless. If you actually need a reason to watch this, there are a few good moments reminiscent of Peel-era idiosyncratic  oddball Avengers style moments, such as the Spectre-like villains meeting at a round table disguised as different colored teddy bears.

It's so bad it's hilarious. My rating does not mean The Avengers is good, it's just so weird, crazy, and stupid at the same time that I find it laughable, even the teddy bear costumes and Sean Connery's accent is silly and ridiculous XP.
I would wrather cut my dick off and shove it up my ass than try and sit through the whole film!

ah the avengers, the Marvel Cinematic Universe' first team up which... oh wait. this movie is so boring that nobody can sit through it without a lot of drugs. to make things worse Sean Connery could have been Morpheus in The Matrix but turned that role down for this disaster.
A very smug film that is woeful at times.
1/10 No Tom Hiddelston

Dr. Emma Peel (Uma Thurman) receives a phone call telling her to go to a gentlemen's club - no women allowed - where she meets John Steed (Ralph Fiennes), agent of The Ministry, for the first time. The two head off to the Ministry to meet Mother (Jim Broadbent), who informs them the Prospero project - an attempt to influence the weather - was sabotaged apparently by Emma Peel. Dr. Peel claims she is innocent, but she is sent to work alongside Steed to find the real culprit. Mother's off-sider, Father (Fiona Shaw), claims Peel suffers from a mental disease. They go off to visit Sir August De Wynter (Sean Connery), an old ally of The Ministry. He takes an instant liking to Peel, as they both share a love of weather. Steed and Emma follow a lead to Wonderland Weather - a business that artificially creates heat or rain with a special machine - where they discover two dead men in teddy bear suits. The members of a secret organisation - led by De Wynter - all wear teddy bear suits to disguise their identities. One of them, however, looks exactly like Emma Peel. Steed arrives in time to save Peel, as the double jumps off a roof and disappears. Steed and Emma go off to visit De Wynter at his mansion but are attacked by mechanical bees. Alice (Eileen Atkins), a Ministry agent, helps them to flee; nevertheless, De Wynter captures Emma who then tries to escape but finds herself trapped due to the mansion's ever-changing floor plan. She smashes her way through a window, and Steed rescues her. Back at Steed's apartment, however, Peel is arrested by Father, as Steed visits Invisible Jones (Patrick MacNee), a man inside The Ministry, to investigate the meaning of a map Steed found at Wonderland Weather. After viewing some photos of failed genetic experiments including cloning (revealing that the other Emma Peel is a clone), Steed determines Father is working with De Wynter. Father and Peel's clone capture Peel but are confronted by Mother, who is then incapacitated. De Wynter, controlling Prospero and the weather, confronts the world's leaders. He boasts that he controls the weather, and they will have to buy the weather from him, will pay a lot for it, and will have until midnight to pay...

"The Avengers" is a 1998 American action spy film adaptation of the British television series of the same name that ran between 1961-1969. Warner Bros., the film's distributor, refused to allow any early press-screenings for movie reviewers that most releases attempt to generate interest in; such a decision is often made when a studio and/or distributor knows a film will not be received well and pre-release reviews would only be negative. The film was originally scheduled to open earlier in June 1998 but was pushed back until August, often referred to as the late-summer "dumping ground" for films that are not felt to be strong or worthy enough to open on the more lucrative holiday weekends in early summer. The film was a notable failure at the box office, grossing only $48 million worldwide, compared to its budget of $60 million. Mick LaSalle, of the San Francisco Chronicle, warned against poor editing and direction, explaining; "There's.......some business involving a dead ringer for Emma going around causing trouble, and there's some mention of the word "cloning." Then all talk of that is dropped. Everything is dropped. After a slow opening, the 90-minute movie jolts into climax mode. What happened to the middle? Clearly, this wasn't just edited but gutted. No doubt they did us all a favor, but it doesn't help. Instead of just being a bad picture, the missing middle makes "The Avengers" a bad and weird and strangely off picture. One example: There's never a moment when Emma and Steed realize who the villain is. At first, they don't know. Next, they're in a titanic battle to the death. At one point, Emma is shackled and floating around in a hot-air balloon. I don't know how she got there. I must have blinked. Due to internal wrangling at Warner Bros., the decision was made to vastly cut down the running time after test screenings, reducing the 115-minute film to 87 minutes, sacrificing much coherence and continuity in the process. Key scenes removed included the opening sequence in which "Mrs. Peel" infiltrates and destroys the Prospero science installation; early trailers included the scene where she says the words "How now brown cow" in a false telephone box to gain admittance. The movie was originally scored by composer Michael Kamen, who included the original Avengers theme; however he was unable to re-score the film after the radical editing, so was forced to drop out. The recut version of the film was scored by Joel McNeely. The original script was used for the film's novelization and included all the material which were first shot and then removed from the film. The original cut has yet to surface; Warner Bros. has no plans to release a director's cut or special edition in any form, despite that director Jeremiah Chechik has offered to recut the film for free. The film was panned by critics. The review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes consensus reads, "A TV spinoff that lacks enough energy to spin, The Avengers is an ineptly written, woefully miscast disaster." The purists disliked it for its disrespect to the original series (particularly the introduction of a romance between Steed and Peel - a carefully ambiguous subject in the series). Newcomers were lost by all of the misfired attempts to capture the mood of the original. Rod Dreher in the New York Post called the film "a big fat gob of maximum crapulosity, the kind of shallow, stupid, big-budget cow pile that smells of Joel Schumacher", referencing the previous summer's likewise poorly received Batman & Robin, which also starred Uma Thurman. David Bianculli stated, "This Avengers film is so horrendously, painfully, and thoroughly awful that it gives other cinematic clunkers like Ishtar and Howard the Duck a good name." Jay Boyer in the Orlando Sentinel said "The Avengers is, without a doubt, the worst movie of the summer". Reception in Britain was equally hostile. The Birmingham Post stated "The Avengers is being slated by critics as the worst film ever made - such a turkey, says one, that the makers should have handed distribution to (mass turkey producer) Bernard Matthews". Alan Jones in The Radio Times stated "The cult 1960s TV series gets royally shafted by Hollywood in this stunningly designed blockbuster that's stunningly awful in every other department... Terrible special effects and zero chemistry between Fiennes and Thurman make this notorious disaster a total waste of everyone's time and energy." Commenting on the truncated released cut of the film, New York Times's Janet Maslin noted, "At a pared-down, barely rational 90 minutes, "The Avengers" is short but not short enough."

I did not grow up with the original "The Avengers" (1961-1969) but I know of the show, the main characters and the actors. This is yet another example of a film that was slaughtered in the editing room when they reduced the 115-minute film to 87 minutes, sacrificing much coherence and continuity in the process. Everything in the film feels random, campy, poor and as said there´s no coherence nor continuity which gives us a very confusing film. With A-list stars like Ralph Fiennes, Uma Thurman and Sean Connery you´d think there would be potential, but the end result is far from it. All three seems to have no idea what´s going on due to mediocre direction. I reckon charm, style and fun was the main pillars of the tv-show, but with the film all of that is not in place. It´s a weird and strange unfunny film in many ways and you really struggle to find anything that is good about it. The effects are shoddy and the script silly in an Austin Powers way. Once the colourful teddybears appears in the film you realise that this film will never recover. 

Trivia: Peter Bart's book "The Gross" covered the film's unfolding disaster in great detail. Among other facts: Warner Brothers greenlit the film largely on the strength of a star-packed cast and their appreciation of Jeremiah Chechik's work on Diabolique (1996) and were horrified when seeing what the first cut was like. The first screening took place in front of a "largely Spanish-speaking, working class" audience in Phoenix, Arizona, who hated the film; the studio then forced Chechik to cut many of his favorite scenes, and conduct reshoots; and the final cut went from 115 to 89 minutes, and was completely incoherent. The studio even refused to hold further test screenings, or to have an official premiere before the film's August 1998 release. Ralph Fiennes said of the film, "I think it's a badge of honor to have a real flop on your resumé".

The late '60s TV show The Avengers was quirky, slightly surrealist but never boring. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for this timely film. There is absolutely no chemistry between the two leads, no witty repartee (only patronising English cultural cliches like "Do you fancy a cup of tea?") and Sean Connery should be memorable as the villain but is given little screen time to make an impression. It is basically the worst kind of British movie- that being a British movie with a Hollywood mentality. Terrible, just bloody terrible old chap.

The late '60s TV show The Avengers was quirky, slightly surrealist but never boring. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for this timely film. There is absolutely no chemistry between the two leads, no witty repartee (only patronising English cultural cliches like "Do you fancy a cup of tea?") and Sean Connery should be memorable as the villain but is given little screen time to make an impression. It is basically the worst kind of British movie- that being a British movie with a Hollywood mentality. Terrible, just bloody terrible old chap.
Failed attempt at remaking the 1960s TV show.

Butchered by studio interference, this maimed version of Chechik take on the 60s classic is oddly fascinating, if bungled. A game cast and good production values are let down by unbalanced tone, a choppy plot and a series of lame, trimmed gags.
Saw this a long time ago and it was forgettable.

A movie has to be pretty bad for me to give it one star. I'm not one of those people who either loves or hates everything, and everything is either five or one stars. (I hate those people though). Most movies are 2,3, or 4 stars, unless they really and truly stand out. This movie deserves its one star.
This was just ridiculous. I had to stop watching
This was an interesting kind of bad

Total misfire. The TV series it's based on is still well regarded. This mess is done in by a terrible script, awful pacing, and poor casting decisions. Warner Bros. released this did the year after "Batman & Robin." Yuck.
Missed the point of the original TV series. Ralph Fiennes is actually pretty good in this. The great Sean Connery's talent is pretty much wasted. Remade somewhat as Kingsman: The Secret Service.
Yuck. Not even Sean Connery adds anything.
What a bloody waste of film, cast and above all characters of Peel and Steed.

Uma Thurman looks great. Nothing else much to write about. Another of those movies which thinks that joining random scientific terms in random order makes a sci fi movie.
Skip it.

This film has bland character, bland dialogue and is trying to be artsy. It fails as a movie and an adaptation. However, since the film tries to be artsy, we are displayed with some interesting visuals, but it does not make up for the rest of the film's faults.

Wonderfully Awful! Bad for theatrical exhibition but decent fun as a television flick.  Cool set designs, cool actors in cool clothes and a good soundtrack along with some colorful cinematography . If this movie had a good and solid story with some captivating action it would have been awesome. There were some good and entertaining ideas here that were just executed poorly.  Still, it's one of my fave "bad movies".

Wow ... this is not a good movie.  I haven't completely decided whether the fault lies with Warner Brothers for cutting 1/4 of its running time or whether there was never much hope of it being any good.  I lean towards the latter.  While I have no doubt that it's incoherent plot is the fault of the studio, it has other issues that seem more fundamental.  The cast is great on paper, but that doesn't seem to translate to the screen.  Fiennes is okay, if not very engaging, but Thurman is pretty terrible.  Connery seems totally adrift.  The action is busy, loud and uninteresting.

Als ich den Film schauen zuerst schauen wollte, habe ich sehr viele schlechte Kritiken davon erfahren. Ich dachte, wenn so gute Darsteller dabei sind, wird es wohl nicht so Übel sein. Ja. Denkste: Der Film ist ja wirklich lächerlich! Das sich die Schauspieler auf so ein Spiel eingelassen hatten, ist mir selber ein Rätsel! Zu einem ist die Geschichte nicht gar so schlecht! (Auch wenn es ein billiger James Bond Story sein könnte.) Aber dies ist so mies umgesetzt worden, dass sogar selbst die Hauptdarsteller bei der Premiere nicht erschienen. Sicher spielen Fiennes und Thurman souverän, aber Sean Connery in einen Teddybär zu verkleiden, ist sogar für ihn unter dem Niveau! Der Film schaut man nur wegen den Schauspielern!
Fazit: Besser ein gutes Drehbuch schreiben, wenn man schon gute Darsteller hat und dazu etwas Ernsthaftes daraus machen!
This was a truly awful film. I can't believe I wasted one of the few sunny Saturday afternoons this summer to watch it.
About the worst movie with a high grade cast like that!
An unbelievably stupid movie with an even stupider plot which features, among other things, Sean Connery and his co-conspirators in rainbow teddy bear costumes.
Don't get me started on that.
Pretty badly decent. So bad that it's ok, with a good performance from Connery.
Awful, they could have tried to make Steed & Peel just a tiny bit like the originals.  But with a blond Steed, the movie was doomed even before it began.

I only watched this because it's one of the few I haven't seen with my #1 British actor, Ralph Fiennes. It was, as the reviewers back in 1998 said, awful, though not un-watchable for a Sunday afternoon at home.  It started out fine, similar to what the TV series was about, but quickly dived into ridiculousness. I didn't feel It had much connection with the '60s TV series with Diana Rigg (a far better Emma Peel than Uma Thurman) and Patrick Macnee. Fiennes handled the role of John Steed very well, as well as the script allowed anyhow. Sean Connery is the villain and he's good as always, again, within the confines of the script. Two things made me go "oh brother":  the giant mechanical bumble bees and Steed kissing Peel. This last thing NEVER would have happened in the original TV series, though the tension was always there. There's other stuff that bugged me too, but I'll stop here. Overall, if you haven't seen it, you're not missing anything.

This is one of the dullest and most boring films I've seen. The characters are bland, the visuals are bland, and the dialogue is bland. Even Sean Connery, the man who stared in the most successful spy movies, couldn't make this movie interesting.

I was a big fan of the original British TV series from the 60's, but I can't say the same of this movie version. It is flashy, with witty dialogue full of inane puns...and they drink a lot of tea. It is interesting to see Sean Connery play a villain.
The film is directed in high style. Overdirected in fact, and hopelessly underwritten.
The sets are dull the charecters are dull the action ha dull and the film is one huge dull joke and I never saw the show

Never saw the original show, but this movie was entertaining. The film spent a lot of time trying to introduce non fans to the feel of this world, an almost goofy James Bond, and almost a rehashed Bondesque plot. Entertaining but I personally wouldn't buy it to own.

Is it bad? Yeah, it's pretty fucking bad. Is it horrible? Not really. It's quite entertaining. It's probably one of my favorite bad movies. The action and acting are mostly good, but it's predictable as all hell and cheesy. The cast is great but it didn't have the director to do it. Seriously, what the fuck was up with those bear suits? I legitimately like the final fight scene, even though it ends in a 'what the fuck?' kind of ending. The film is stylish in the wrong ways. Case in point: THE FUCKING BEAR SUITS.

I'm giving The Avengers a 4/10 mostly for acting, action and the fact that it didn't take itself too seriously.
Looks well made but you have no sense of suspence.
That Sean Connery fever dream you had after eating indian food. Swallow some tums and try to forget it.
Eh boy...beau petit navet comme film ca. Et que dire des jeux de mots discutables.
Nice tribute, bad roll for Sean Conery.
This film is not as bad as everyone says!
One of the worst movie I've ever seen!

While perhaps not the best adaptation of a tv show in film form, it is still a rather fun watch.

It is a blast seeing Sean in the role of 'bad guy', one that he seems eager to play. He is so versatile an actor, that he can easily play both hero and bad guy to a tee.

On the other hand, thinking back on this film, I must admit that both Uma and Ralph played rather flat characters, a flaw that I believe the script is to blame. It also was obviously trying to break the Unresolved Sexual Tension between the original actors of each character, Rigg and Macnee.

Over all, if you like a silly spinoff and Sean Connery, then I suggest you watch it.
blaaaahhh,,,, #sorry
Stupid movie but kind of fun to watch.  It seemed to mimic the series well.  Fiennes was truly a joy to watch in this role and Connery looks as if he enjoys being the bad guy for once.
1998 Avengers is a dull, unfunny and unfathomably boring piece of shit
Poor move! It was a wonderful television series!
Still awful nearly 15 years on. Note to Warner Bros, when you cut 25 minutes out of a film, make sure the remaining 90 make sense.

There are a lot of problems here, where to begin... For a movie that is supposed to be primarily an action movie it forgot to bring the action. It is dull because the threat of the villain has such a small focus. Sean Connery is barley in this movie. The villain could have been good and his plot to control the weather seems like a winner. Instead, they ruin everything by trying to do too much.  Forcing an evil cloned Emma Peel, a boardroom of evil teddy bears, mechanical bees, and a random unexplained man of mystery (Eddie Izzard) were all painful mistakes. All of these scenes should have been given to Connery to build his character and make a more coherent story. The movie wrongfully puts all of its chips on the playful banter between Steed and Mrs Peel. This may have been the charm of the 60s TV show but it feels very forced and unnatural here. Ralph Fiennes was an alright Steed but Uma Therman was too cold and mechanical for her part. They just do not have the chemistry that was essential to make this work. This fails in nearly every way and only takes away from the Avengers name.
One of my childhood movies, boring for most but a guilty pleasure of mine.
I am a pretty big Uma Thurman fan, but this movie is crap.  Should have been scrapped by the studio

The movie was cheesy if I ever saw one. 
The graphics were not the best either. The music was alright. The font for the opening credits was too small which made it difficult to read. You were not invested in the characters very much at all. They could have killed the good guys and cared very little because no background was given to like the characters.
Connery kills a Care Bear. Yeah, it's that shitty.
Even Eddie Izzard couldn't save this muddled mess
should have been a career ender for all involved but somehow they "weathered the storm"

A great cast put together for (yet another) remake that somewhere along the line falls flat. It took a drubbing from critics and fans, but whatever caused this film to fail, it sure as hell wasn't the acting. Nothing wrong there, although I have to say Uma isn't near the beauty Diana Rigg was in that role. Damn she was hot.

I really wanted to like this movie, but it's an absolute mess. I love the original series and there are many elements of the original that work well here, but the film is such a grab bag of randomness that it ends up being completely incoherent. I blame primarily the script for the failure to adapt the TV series. Director Jeremiah S. Chechik brings a lot of style and a visually engaging style and it should have been a lot more fun seeing Sean Connery playing what could have been a fun send up of James Bond villains, but overall the film is a major disappointment.
The tv-series was so much better ;p
DiÃ¡logos vazios e interpretaÃ§Ãµes dignas de crianÃ§as o filme e uma misÃ (C)ria..

"The Avengers" is based on a classic British television programme (yes, that's what they call them over there) that I am largely unfamiliar with, so I cannot compare and contrast the two.  That said, I found this celluloid adaptation to be, though not great and certainly not excellent, a somewhat amusing spy spoof in the vein of "Get Smart."
Let's start with the positives: By far, the best thing about "The Avengers" are some of the crazy visuals.  I don't want to give away too much, but I will say that they're things few denizens of this planet will ever see elsewhere, which is part of what makes movies in general fun and entertaining.  Also, "The Avengers" may have been rated "PG-13," but it barely deserved it.  The violence was largely bloodless and very much in the style of a "TV-Y7-FV" Saturday morning show; about as sexual as it got was seeing a man's backside; and, there was very little profanity.  Even Uma Thurman ("Kill Bill") stayed fully clothed throughout the film.  Speaking of her, she and her co-stars, Sean Connery (a former "James Bond") and Ralph Fiennes ("Harry Potter") did very well in the movie.
However, there were some significant issues that kept this one from being a winner: First off, despite posing as a spy spoof and having a smattering of humor, "The Avengers" wasn't as funny as it could have been.  I really expected to laugh a lot more than I did.  Additionally, despite the content being mostly clean, smoking was in overabundance in the film.  The film's hour-and-a-half running time felt longer than it was, and that wasn't a good sign.
So, my thoughts? If you're an Anglophile and have yet to see this, you should at least rent it just to say that you have seen it.  Those who couldn't care less about British media should just stay away; seriously, as insane as the visuals are in "The Avengers," it's not worth sitting through the rest of the film.

Is it wrong that I kind of like this movie?  Don't get me wrong, it doesn't even compare to most films of its type, and the 2.5 stars is relative to what other people rate it.  I guess I just have to ask, what else were you expecting?  The original television show was campy, outrageous, implausible, and sometimes downright bizarre.  Does this film capture that?  It seems to.  Does it do much else?  No.

★★ (out of four)

Years ago there was another film called "The Avengers"  Instead of being based on the comic book it was a remake of a 1960's era British Spy television series, staring Patric MacNee.  Well, not surprisingly it has been dumbed down for more recent audiences.

Ralph Fiennes plays British spy John Steed and Uma Thurman is his partner, Emma Peel.  They battle an amateurish script which has them battling an evil genius (Sean Connery) who plans to hold England by the throat by sending bad weather their way.

The plot is pretty silly and never goes anywhere interesting. Obviously, some big money was thrown into the production.  I guarantee the special effects team recieved more dough than the scriptwriters.

[IMG]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v48/Zeppo1/Aveneger.jpg[/IMG]
How could just not love 1 but 2 Uma Thurmans in the same film?  Brilliant!
I honestly couldn't get through the first 20 minutes. :(. I turned it off and usually I can't do that.
British spies try to prevent a mad man trying to rule the world with his weather changing machine.
cheesy and unoriginal.
Eventhough this movie is different it is a good different..some might not like this movie..but i enjoyed it
Why? This film possesses nothing. It attempts to use a dumb joke over and over and tries to use good actors, but still fails miserably.
Nonsensical and muddled. With the Schumacher Batman movies the nadir of mid-to-late 90s action movies. Even the casting was confusing.
Sean Connery..... All I can ask is.... Why'd you do it. You're a timeless actor.... Why this? Why Carebear suits? Was someone threatening you to do this film.

This movie was not as bad as many people say it was.There are many flaws in the movie, but it is still enjoyable, if not a little cheesy. First of all, the acting was subpar, except by Connery who does his best with the material. The plot was pretty nonsensical. If Sir August de Wynter wanted people to pay for the weather from him, or he would keep making it colder, wouldn't he die as well of cold just like the others? The action was just okay as well. On the flip side, the special effects were pretty good and the costumes and props weren't bad. Overall, an enjoyable cheesy flick that is let down by bad acting, terrible screenplay and only okay action.
I saw it in theaters and walked out halfway into it. There are better things to do with ones time. Whenever this film gets mentioned I recall just how awful it was.

Even though it's not quite as good as the series, The Avengers entertains all the same. This adaptation artfully mixes the hip style of the 60s with the techno traditional of the 90s. Great set designs come alongside Sean Connery's decent portrayal of Sir August De Wynter, a madman bent on world domination by way of the weather. Ralph fiennes plays an average John Steed; though I have to wonder how the movie would've done with Tom Wilkinson instead, as well as with a bit more snappy humor. Uma Thurman portrays Emma Peel not quite as spot-on as Diana Rigg, but oh well. At least Patrick Macnee (the original John Steed) makes a brief cameo as Invisible Jones, which is enough to add some positive props to the film's structure. All in all, I was pleasantly surprised by the way the makers of this movie attempted to revive the series by combining the old with the new, which is a lot more than The Wild Wild West, Lost in Space, and The A-Team can say for themselves. "Rain or shine, all is MINE!" -Sir August De Wynter.
It was a valiant effort, but lots of cutting and editing killed this for good.  It's fairly enjoyable for the first half too.

Ralph Fiennes, Uma Thurman, and Jim Broadbent in a spy movie where the villain is played by Sean Connery? That sounds awesome! What could possibly go wrong?

Apparently, everything. I will admit that the visuals are pretty awesome, and the final battle between Sean Connery and Ralph Fiennes was surprisingly epic, but everything else is so boring it's not even funny. I mean, WOW - there truly, absolutely was no human emotion in this movie whatsoever. It really was astonishing. The directing was amateurish at best, and the whole thing seemed rushed - a lot of scenes were short and seemed to go nowhere, and most of the movie was more disjointed than The Last Airbender. This movie really is as bad as they say, folks. Ye have been warned.
is there any way I can give it no stars

The Avengers was one of the cleverest and most original television programmes of the nineteen-sixties. Unfortunately, The Avengers cinematic adaptation is a mind-bending British spy adventure that was rightly critically condemned for his outlandish plot, ridiculous action sequences and appalling acting.  As a fan of the famous sixties television show, The Avengers should have been a cinematic triumph. Boasting an incredible cast that included a suave Ralph Fiennes and a villainous Sean Connery, The Avengers ought to have encapsulated an incredible series. Nonetheless, The Avengers is a missed cinematic opportunity; however, the movie does play homage to series and unless you are an avid fan of the series, I doubt you would appreciate the films numerous in-jokes and references. Even so, permit the film one viewing at least and then revisit the original series and for a glimpse of the true Steed and Mrs. Peel.

Basically one big long bore that's allegedly 90 minutes long but feels like 4 hours. The special effects look like the graphics of a Playstation 1 game, the script is supposed to be witty but it just comes off as annoyingly smug. Speaking of annoyingly smug, Ralph Fiennes character is so pretentious and stereotypically British that I might have actually hated him more than his villain roles in Harry Potter and Schindler's List combined. The rest of the cast doesn't fare much better: Jim Broadbent is usually a good actor even in terrible movies but seems bored here (and I don't blame him),  Sean Connery's performance is actually shockingly bland save a few scenes and the film also manages to exist as further proof that Uma Thurman needs to think a bit harder when picking her non Quentin Tarantino projects. Its rare that a movie is so bad, so lifeless and manages to be a trainwreck on so many levels that its not even enjoyable for unintentional hilarity. All in all dreadfully boring affair.
It's even worse that you heard it was.

The initial opening offers an intriguing spy film but everything after is a weird hybrid of exposition and tea inclusion. I can't fault the actors who seem to be doing the best with what they are handed, the overall tone might have worked if the filmmakers knew where they were taking the film. The first 30 minutes are okay, setting the scene for the oddball world here and if it was to continue with this story, it may have worked. The film takes a turn with the introduction of Sean Connery, not a bad choice for the villain but he is very one dimensional. The teddy bear scene is quite inspired but this is a prime example of a hybrid weirdness that doesn't float well, the film is lost within its own ambitions, maybe atudio interference. I have heard that the film was cut heavily and you can't fault the director if the studio abandoned the filmmaker, if it was terrible and left alone by the studio, by all means we throw blame at the director. The film is cut badly and shifts all around the place and is another Warner Bros tv remake that is terrible, Wild Wild West is about on par and never captures the campiness it needed to succeed. Fingers crossed for a longer directors cut in the future. 18-09-2017.

Worst film I've ever had the misfortune of watching. I think everyone should be forced to sit through this so we all have a barometer of film making ineptitude. It is staggeringing poor. The acting, the costumes, the plot, the whole thing is remarkable for the depths it plunges.

I am among the very small number of original "The Avengers" fans that actually dare to say they like this movie. I just think it's a very fun, classic late-90's Bond-esque action/adventure flick that has some pretty good production values. Plus, Joel McNeely provides an excellent score (specifically the movie's main title, as well as his reorchestrations of the original theme from "The Avengers") that I think would make him the perfect replacement for David Arnold if, heavens forbid, Arnold ever stepped down (remember he said he was going to? He said it, I BELIEVE after both "Die Another Day" and "Casino Royale", but he ended up coming back, which I'm glad he did). 

That said, I do understand the film's week points. I think a lot of the negativity of the film comes from the script. The thing is: the script is almost perfect.... for a TV episode of "The Avengers". The writer(s) does a wonderful job (for the most part) of capturing the dialogue style of the original TV series. However, the problem is... this isn't a TV series episode. This is a motion picture. And dialogue that works for a television episode just doesn't translate well on the big screen. So this is, I think, the film's biggest flaw. 

Another thing is that, THOUGH I admit I do adapt to them throughout the movie, I still think that Uma Thurman and especially Ralph Fiennes were two of the weirdest choices for Steed and Emma Peel. Ralph Fiennes almost can't be taken seriously at first because he is just so small and frail, like he almost looks like a little kid in an oversized suit. And Uma Thurman I've just never really been a big fan of. But again, they do grow on me throughout the movie.

Always a pleasure to watch a movie with Sean Connery in it... However, this is not one of my favorite Sean Connery movies for the pure and simple reason of: ...I don't like seeing him as a bad guy. Sean Connery should never play a bad guy. Not because he is bad at doing so! Quite the contrary! But based solely on his cool factor and how much I like him... he must always play a good guy. Forever.

I think one of the weirdest things is that I really feel like he looks older in "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade" than he does in any of his mid-to-late 90's films.

I know.. that doesn't really have anything to do with anything. But...


So, yeah... Definitely can understand some of the reasons for the negative ratings. But I really do love this movie. The TV Series is BETTER, of course (The '67 Series is still my favorite), but the movie really is fun.

Imagine taking Pierce Brosnan away from the plot lines of his James Bond movies and instructing him to make as many puns as possible while sounding as British, arrogant, and pompous as he could.  Next, throw in a completely ridiculous storyline and hope that the promise Uma Thurman in a skin tight leather outfit is enough to convince people to sit through this trash.  This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen.  How they got Uma and Sean Connery is beyond me.

Not to be mistaken for the upcoming AVENGERS movie in 2012. This film is based on the 1960's TV show of the same name. The movie is slow at times but overall does have itâs charm. The most memorable scene is when a bunch of mechanical wasps attack our pair of spy heroes but even that isn't much to work with. The film does include some interesting oddities but unless you are just in love with English accents, Uma Thurman and mediocrity, you can go ahead and skip this one. THE AVENGERS and THE NEW AVENGERS were both used by the TV show, neither has anything to do with Stan Lee's superhero collective.

(from The Watermark, 08/20/98)
Let's see: They're not making any more Batman films, so what other 1960's TV show could they possibly use to make a bad big-screen movie? The Avengers! It was so senseless, I just sat there saying, "What in the world is going on here?" All I could manage to figure out was Bad Guy Connery wants to dominate the world's weather. Good Guys Fiennes, a stuffed shirt by-the-book secret agent, and Thurman, his well-dressed sexy partner, don't want him to. You guessed it: it's yet another one of those films where too much thought is put into the art direction, the scenic design, and the costumes, while nobody pays any attention to the story or script. This is getting really tired, Tinseltown! Fiennes and Thurman are both as beautiful as always, and do what they can with their roles, but there really isn't any chemistry between them. Connery, turning in a forgettable performance in a forgettable role, isn't an even slightly interesting bad guy. I've never seen the TV show, but I can't imagine it got so popular from being this bad. Queer Quotient: That catsuit that Thurman wears is pretty flawless, and we do get a seated butt-shot of Fiennes. In my book, he is more than fine.

The Avengers has a good cast, but man does this film fall flat! It's not quite a terrible film, watchable at least, but I feel it could've at least potentially been a passable to okay film but it's hindered by the questionable fate that many have wondered about this film: the fact the studio cut off 30 min from this movie after test screenings, which resulted in the film's many plot holes and continuity errors. Would the extra footage made a great difference? Possibly, but we'll never know, but for what we've got here, this film is flawed plot wise. Aside from that, the film still has errors that couldn't be fixed, such as the confusing dialogue, dull characters, and flat humor. The action is average, but probably the only small bright spot in this film, but even that isn't all so salvageable and couldn't save this film. If this film wants to change my mind... bring out the original cut, but the theatrical cut we've got... a weak spy action flick.

British Ministry secret agent John Steed, teams up with Emma Peel to stop Sir August De Wynter from destroying the world with a weather changing machine. They are called in to investigate Prospero, a plot to blackmail Britain by controlling the weather. Emma Peel is suspected of being involved but it is discovered that she has a double who works for the real baddie, Sir August de Wynter. He threatens to freeze Britain, at one point unleashing a blizzard on Trafalgar Sqaure.

in the what were people and critics expecting department comes 1998's the Avengers.
a movie that im not afraid to say is thouroughly enjoyable because of two things.
#1 i was a huge fan of the campy, often times ''Adam West batman silly 60's original.
and #2 because of that fact ''I GET THE JOKE.
people who went into this film expecting Dr No or Diamonds are forever clearly NEVER saw the campy original series that this movie is so carefully paying Homage to right up to the Numerous Tea references and the cameo ( sort of ) by the Original John Steed himself.
the Avengers is ( just like 2008's Mummy Tomb of the Dragon Emperor ) a criminally maligned film that doesn't take itself too seriously, Gee, just like the original series did in its own Mod Tongue and cheek way.
the movie doesn't waste too much time with exposition, its all cool style over substance, and guess what, it works,but only if you stop over-analyzing it and let it work its charms and stop holding it up to its predecessor.
Sean Connery plays an excellent baddie as sir August de Winter, a mad man hell bent on controlling the world thru weather and ultra cool John Steed and Ema Peel ( Uma Thurman looking as Sexy as Ever )are off to stop him and stop him in Style.
the Sexy Banter between Ray Fiennes and Uma Thurman engaged me in a way that Dianna Rigg and Patrick Macnee's respectful banter didn't.
just like the Original Ms Peel Uma's Ms Peel is Drop Dead Sexy, so This Version of John Steed goes after her.
it makes Sense. at least if you have Male Genitalia.
the movie clearly from the get go exhibits a style and polish just not seen in Today's mass marketed Junk like GI-JOE or the awful Mass produced Marvel comics movies.
and again, DID ANY OF YOU SEE THE ORIGINAL SERIES?
i have to keep going back to this because i have seen EVERY episode of the avengers from the Diana Rigg era.
they were silly and WAY over the top to say the least.
this movie was like Dr Shivago compared to some of the silliness that went on in those old shows.
in 2009 after much more Horrible films like ( anything Michael Bey or Rob Zombie has remade ) a whole new audience is beginning to see this film for what it was.
1998's Avengers was meant as silly, stylish fun and if you went in expecting anything more than that, then the joke ultimately was on you now wasn't it old Boy?
i look forward to seeing the Avengers every September as part of an English themed block of films and like an old friend it never fails to deliver just what it promises.
you want art go rent The Dark Knight.
the Avengers is Silly fun.
in closing, this is the perfect Mod film to accompany any Block of British films in your English cinema marathon.
cool, sexy and stylish, 1998's Avengers may have been '' Too cool and Mod'' for the Oh Too serious late 90's.
and judging by the negative reviews its received from many of you so-called Avengers fans who still don't get it even a decade later?, it appears that im 100% right in my theory.

The TV series had a great sound to go along with its unequaled style, mod along with a bit of cool.

Despite how much they tried, Fiennes and Thurman have nothing compared to the originals, Macnee and Riggs.

This movie lacks the style, wit, suspense, and ambiance of the TV series.
